Award.AwardTitle: NSF East Asia and Pacific Summer Institute for FY 2012 in China
Award.AbstractNarration:
This action funds Natalie Juda of Scripps Institution of Oceanography at the University of California, San Diego to conduct a research project, entitled "Evaluating the mantle source composition of Antarctic oceanic and continental lavas" during the summer of 2012 at the Chinese Academy of Sciences Guangzhou Institute of Geochemistry in Guangzhou, Guangdong, China. The host scientist is Jifeng Xu.

The Intellectual Merit lies in isotopic analysis of samples collected along a transect from oceanic to continental crust in the northern Ross Sea, Antarctica. Combining petrographic, geochronologic, geochemical, and isotopic analyses of samples provides estimates of age and composition of intraplate magmatism in the Adare basin of the northern Ross Sea.

These geochemical data are fundamental to a full appreciation of regional and local scale patterns in mantle composition, mantle geodynamics and crustal production in Antarctica. The proposed characterization of the Adare Basin Seamount lavas is a necessary first-order constraint for modeling the mantle source and origin of Cenozoic magmatism in West Antarctica and SW Pacific region, as well as the tectono-magmatic processes associated with continental rifting as a whole.

Broader Impacts of an EAPSI fellowship include providing the Fellow a first-hand research experience outside the U.S.; an introduction to the science, science policy, and scientific infrastructure of the respective location; and an orientation to the society, culture and language. These activities meet the NSF goal to educate for international collaborations early in the career of its scientists, engineers, and educators, thus ensuring a globally aware U.S. scientific workforce.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The mechanisms that shape the earth’s surface into continents and oceans have been studied intensely particularly since the advancement of the theory of plate tectonics in the middle of the previous century. Studies have utilized emerging geophysical and geochemical methods to understand current plate dynamics as well as past continental movements. Continental rifting is an integral part of plate tectonics as the mechanism for continental separation, eventually forming ocean basins. There are few locations on the current earth’s surface where continental rifting is actively occurring (most notably the East African rift whose volcanic products include famous mountain volcanoes such as Mt. Kilimanjaro, however the West Antarctic rift system is also active and less well studied with isolated volcanic centers spread along its axis including Mt. Erebus). 

The purpose of this study was to conduct a targeted geochemical study of volcanic rocks formed as a product of volcanism related to the West Antarctic Rift System to characterize the chemical composition of the mantle beneath the region. Different mechanisms involved in the continental rifting will show in different chemistries of the underlying mantle (e.g. a plume source has a different signature than the regular asthenospheric mantle beneath the crust).  To that end, samples were collected from seamounts from the ocean floor in the northwest Ross Sea region of Antarctica to obtain a lava sample with geochemical signatures most like the mantle beneath from which it formed. In addition, samples were collected in a range of locations from seafloor to terrestrial samples from the continent. However, the more terrestrial lavas are variably affected by contamination from the continental crust through which they erupt as well as the sub-continental lithospheric mantle which obscure the signature of the asthenospheric mantle source of the volcanism.

The isotopic system of rhenium (Re) and osmium (Os) is used to characterize the source of the magma from which the volcanic rocks were produced. The Re-Os isotope system has great potential to constrain crustal contamination and possible sub-continental lithospheric mantle (SCLM) contribution in terrestrial lava samples. Lavas passing through continental material to erupt at the surface are more susceptible to alteration through contact with the continental material and this will affect the isotopic ratio of Re and Os because osmium behaves compatibly during partial melting of the mantle while rhenium and the elements in the more conventional isotopic systems behave incompatibly (i.e. when the mantle melts to produce a magma, Os will preferentially remain in the residual solid mantle instead of passing into the liquid magma).

Samples for this study were collected through several individual research groups and powdered rocks were brought to the Guangzhou Institute of Geochemistry in Guangzhou, China for analysis. At this institute I was taught the techniques necessary to chemically separate and purify the elements used for analysis (Re and Os) as well as analytical techniques in order to measure the concentrations and isotopic ratios (Thermal Ionization Mass Spectrometry in negative ion mode, aka NTIMS). Once taught, I conducted all the sample preparation and completed analyses for thirty individual samples and twenty repeats with the assistance of graduate students at the institute.

The rocks show an increasing Os isotopic ratio in more continental samples as expected with greater continental contamination. Within the samples from the seafloor, there is an increasing trend in isotopic ratios towards the continent.
